awd_titl_txt: Applications of Representation Theory in Commutative Algebra
awd_abstract_narration:
This project involves the study of problems from several branches of algebra. Commutative algebra studies sets defined by polynomial equations. The first and second part of the project are devoted to studying polynomial equations defining certain sets characterized geometrically. The third part of this project will be a systematic study of certain kinds of graphs from a geometric point of view.

This project consists of several interrelated parts. The first part is to study the structure of generic rings for finite free resolutions. The principal investigator proposes to develop his discovery of a link between the generic ring for resolutions of length 3 and Kac-Moody Lie algebras related to T-shaped graphs. The second part is related to calculating local cohomology. The PI plans to develop his calculation of local cohomology for certain classes of commutative rings.  The third part involves several other projects on noncommutative algebra. The PI will study picture groups defined for modulated quivers and the geometry of the components of representation spaces for quivers with relations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI worked on the structure of finite free resolutions of ideals (we can think of ideals as collections of polynomial equations). The free resolutions are recursive objects that contain lots of information on the equations in an ideal.

The PI discovered a structure on free resolutions of length 3 (for lenght 1 and 2 it was previously known).

This structure relates free resolutions in question to a famous Cartan-Killing classification of simple Lie algebras.

 

In this way the discovered structure allows to understand in which cases the ideals in question can be classified and which cases such classification should not be possible.

 

One of the key outcomes was the related discovery of certain key examples of perfect ideals of codimension 3 and Gorenstein ideals of codimension 4. It is now clear that without these examples the attempts to classify such ideals were doomed fo failure.

The whole project was the main one for the PI for many years because it is quite basic, it relates to the work of Hilbert that started  comutative algebra.

 

In an unrelated project, joint with M. Aprodu, G. Farkas, S. Papadima, C. Raicu the PI gave a new proof of so-calle Green conjecture for general canonical curve. This is a basic result concerning equations defining curves in higher dimensional spaces. The conjecture was previously proved by C. Voisin over complex numbers, but our proof works over fields of arbirary characteristic.

In another project the PI jointly with A. Lorincz proved results on so-called D-modules for subreguar representations.
